text:
Code
library(ggplot2)
library(plotly)
library(quantmod)
library(tidyquant)
library(tidyverse) 
library(dplyr)

title: Data Visulization
text:
Global Renewable Energy Growth Trends
The data, sourced from the International Energy Agency (IEA), highlights a clear structural shift in the global energy system. While fossil fuels and hydro power historically dominated capacity additions, the past two decades have been characterized by the rapid acceleration of solar and wind energy. In particular, solar capacity has exhibited exponential growth since the early 2010s, outpacing all other sources, while wind energy has demonstrated steady, sustained expansion. By contrast, hydro capacity additions have remained relatively stable, reflecting geographical and environmental constraints. Nuclear additions appear limited in scale, indicating stagnation compared to renewables. Overall, the figure underscores the transition towards low-carbon energy systems, with solar and wind emerging as the primary drivers of global renewable capacity growth.


Code
data <- read.csv("data/renewable-capacity.csv")
p <- ggplot(data, aes(x = Year, y = Capacity, color = Entity)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  labs(
    title = "Global Renewable Energy Capacity by Source",
    subtitle = "Comparison across Solar, Wind, Hydro, etc.",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Capacity (GW)",
    color = "Energy Source"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )

interactive_plot <- ggplotly(p, tooltip = c("x", "y", "Entity"))
interactive_plot

title: Data Visulization
section: Oil Prices vs. Renewable and Traditional Energy ETFs
text:
Oil Prices vs. Renewable and Traditional Energy ETFs
This figure presents a comparative time-series analysis of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil prices (sourced from the Federal Reserve Economic Data, FRED) alongside two exchange-traded funds (ETFs) from Yahoo Finance: the iShares Global Clean Energy ETF (ICLN), representing the renewable energy sector, and the Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLE), representing traditional fossil-fuel–based energy firms.
The visualization employs a dual-axis line chart, with WTI oil prices displayed on the left axis and the ETF prices displayed on the right axis. This design enables a clear comparison of the dynamics between commodity markets and equity markets tied to energy. The temporal alignment of the series allows for the identification of co-movements and divergences.
From the figure, one can observe several key patterns. Periods of sharp volatility in oil prices—such as the downturn around 2008 and the collapse in early 2020—are mirrored by fluctuations in energy-sector equities, though the magnitude and persistence of these responses differ across renewable and traditional ETFs. Notably, while XLE tends to correlate more closely with oil price movements, ICLN demonstrates partial decoupling, reflecting the structural shift toward renewable energy sources whose valuation drivers are less directly dependent on crude oil prices.


Code
etf_symbols <- c("ICLN", "XLE")

etf_data <- tq_get(etf_symbols,
                   from = "2005-01-01",
                   to = Sys.Date(),
                   get = "stock.prices")

etf_data <- etf_data %>%
  select(symbol, date, adjusted)

wti <- read.csv("data/WTIprice.csv")

wti <- wti %>%
  rename(date = observation_date) %>%
  mutate(date = as.Date(date)) %>%
  rename(WTI = POILWTIUSDM) %>%
  filter(!is.na(WTI))

fig <- plot_ly() %>%
  
  add_lines(data = wti, x = ~date, y = ~WTI,
            name = "WTI Crude Oil", yaxis = "y1",
            line = list(color = "black")) %>%
  
  add_lines(data = subset(etf_data, symbol == "ICLN"),
            x = ~date, y = ~adjusted,
            name = "ICLN (Renewable ETF)", yaxis = "y2",
            line = list(color = "green")) %>%
  
  add_lines(data = subset(etf_data, symbol == "XLE"),
            x = ~date, y = ~adjusted,
            name = "XLE (Energy ETF)", yaxis = "y2",
            line = list(color = "blue")) %>%
  layout(
    title = "WTI Oil Price vs Renewable (ICLN) and Energy (XLE) ETFs",
    xaxis = list(title = "Date"),
    yaxis = list(title = "WTI Oil Price (USD)", side = "left"),
    yaxis2 = list(title = "ETF Price (USD)", overlaying = "y", side = "right"),
    legend = list(x = 0.05, y = 0.95)
  )

fig

title: Data Visulization
text:
Annual electric vehicle sales (2010–2024)
Data from the IEA Global EV Outlook illustrate the rapid acceleration of EV adoption worldwide, with particularly strong growth in major markets such as China, the United States, and Europe.


Code
df <- read.csv("data/EV.csv")
df_long <- df %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = -Entity, 
    names_to = "Year", 
    values_to = "EV_Sales"
  ) 
df_clean <- df_long %>%
  mutate(
    Year = str_remove(Year, "^X") %>% as.integer(),
    EV_Sales = EV_Sales %>%
      str_replace_all(",", "") %>%  
      str_trim() %>%                
      na_if("") %>%                 
      as.numeric()
  )

entities <- c("World", "China", "USA", "United Kingdom")
df_subset <- df_clean %>% filter(Entity %in% entities)

# 
ggplot(df_subset, aes(x = Year, y = EV_Sales, fill = Entity)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge", alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_line(aes(color = Entity, group = Entity), size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(aes(color = Entity), size = 2) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") +
  labs(
    title = "Global Electric Vehicle Sales Growth (2010–2024)",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Annual EV Sales (units)",
    fill = "Region/World",
    color = "Region/World"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Data Visulization
text:
Global carbon pricing trends
The carbon price trajectory between 1990 and 2020 exhibits a pronounced peak around 1997, followed by a subsequent decline. The 1997 peak coincides with the adoption of the Kyoto Protocol and the initiation of early carbon pricing mechanisms, during which supply constraints and nascent market structures likely drove temporarily elevated prices. In the years following 2000, the global average carbon price stabilizes within the range of USD 20–40 per ton, reflecting the expansion and maturation of carbon pricing instruments—including carbon taxes and emissions trading systems—across multiple jurisdictions. This stabilization indicates a broadening of market coverage and the integration of diverse mechanisms, though prices remain below levels typically considered necessary to achieve long-term climate mitigation targets.


Code
df <- read.csv("data/Carbonprice.csv")
df_long <- df %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = starts_with("X"), 
    names_to = "Year",
    values_to = "Value"
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    Year = as.integer(str_remove(Year, "^X")), 
    HasPolicy = ifelse(is.na(Value) | Value == "", 0, 1)
  )




Code
df_world_price <- df_long %>%
  group_by(Year) %>%
  summarise(
    mean_price = mean(Value, na.rm = TRUE),
    median_price = median(Value, na.rm = TRUE)
  )

ggplot(df_world_price, aes(x = Year)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = mean_price, color = "Mean"), size = 1.2, na.rm = TRUE) +
  geom_line(aes(y = median_price, color = "Median"), size = 1.2, linetype = "dashed", na.rm = TRUE) +
  labs(title = "Global carbon pricing trends",
       x = "Year", y = "Price ($/tCO₂e)", color = "Statistic") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Data Visulization
section: Global investment in power generation technologies (2015–2025)
text:
Global investment in power generation technologies (2015–2025)
Investments in renewables have grown steadily, reflecting declining technology costs and supportive policy frameworks, whereas spending on coal (unabated) continues its long-term decline due to climate concerns and competitiveness issues. Nuclear power shows moderate but consistent growth, suggesting its role as a low-carbon complement to renewables. By contrast, oil and natural gas (unabated) investments exhibit volatility, influenced by global fuel price dynamics and shifting demand expectations. The comparative evolution of these categories underscores the structural shift in global power systems, where renewables are emerging as the dominant investment destination while unabated fossil-based power steadily loses ground.


Code
df <- read.csv("data/investment.csv")
df_long <- df %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = -1, 
    names_to = "Year", 
    values_to = "Investment"
  ) %>%
  rename(Category = 1) %>%
  mutate(
    Year = as.numeric(str_remove(Year, "^X")),  
    Investment = as.numeric(Investment)
  )%>%
  mutate(Type = case_when(
    Category %in% c("Fossil fuels", "Clean Fuels") ~ "Fuel",
    Category %in% c("Renewables", "Nuclear", "Coal (unabated)", "Oil and natural gas (unabated)") ~ "Power"
  ))
df_power <- df_long %>% filter(Type == "Power")
p_power <- ggplot(df_power, aes(x = Year, y = Investment, fill = Category)) +
  geom_area(alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Global Energy Investment: Power Generation Sources",
       x = "Year", y = "Investment (billion USD)") +
  theme_minimal()

p_power_interactive <- ggplotly(p_power)
p_power_interactive

title: Data Souces
text: The International Energy Agency (IEA) provides comprehensive, high-quality datasets on global energy production and consumption. Specifically, their renewable energy statistics track solar, wind, hydro, and bioenergy generation across different countries and regions. This dataset enables analysis of seasonality, structural growth, and geographic distribution of renewable adoption over time. The data is primarily available in annual and monthly time-series formats and is widely used in policy and academic research. For this project, we will focus on renewable generation from 1990 to the present. Data can be accessed through the IEA Data Browser

title: Data Souces
text: The International Energy Agency (IEA) provides comprehensive, high-quality datasets on global energy production and consumption. Specifically, their renewable energy statistics track solar, wind, hydro, and bioenergy generation across different countries and regions. This dataset enables analysis of seasonality, structural growth, and geographic distribution of renewable adoption over time. The data is primarily available in annual and monthly time-series formats and is widely used in policy and academic research. For this project, we will focus on renewable generation from 1990 to the present. Data can be accessed through the IEA Data Browser

title: Data Souces
section: Data Source 2 – U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)
text:
Data Source 2 – U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)





The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) publishes official statistics on global energy markets, including fossil fuel consumption, production, and pricing. This dataset includes historical oil prices (e.g., Brent crude), natural gas benchmarks, and coal usage, which provide insight into the decline of fossil fuels and volatility in energy markets. The data is updated regularly and made available via the EIA Open Data API, which allows time-series extraction of daily, monthly, and annual series. For this project, fossil fuel consumption and pricing trends from 1980 onward will be analyzed to compare against renewable energy adoption.

title: Data Souces
text:
Data Source 3 – Yahoo Finance





Yahoo Finance provides historical financial market data, including stock prices, indices, and exchange rates. For this project, we will collect stock price information for major clean energy companies (e.g., NextEra Energy, Tesla, Ørsted, Enphase) and fossil fuel companies (e.g., ExxonMobil, Chevron). This allows us to compare market valuation trends and volatility between renewable and traditional energy firms. We will also track clean energy ETFs (e.g., ICLN, TAN) to measure sector-level performance. You can find the data at Yahoo Finance

title: Data Souces
section: Data Source 4 – Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED)
text:
Data Source 4 – Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED)





FRED, maintained by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, provides macroeconomic time-series data such as energy consumption, electricity generation, and commodity prices. For this project, we will extract U.S. time-series on renewable electricity production, natural gas prices, and West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil prices. This dataset will be used to study energy price cycles, structural breaks, and relationships between fossil fuel prices and renewable adoption. You can find the data at FRED API

title: Data Souces
section: Data Source 5 – World Bank Carbon Pricing Dashboard
text:
Data Source 5 – World Bank Carbon Pricing Dashboard





The World Bank Carbon Pricing Dashboard provides global data on carbon taxes and emissions trading systems. These time-series are valuable for analyzing policy shocks and their impact on renewable adoption and energy investment flows. For example, we can test whether countries that introduced carbon pricing mechanisms show faster growth in renewable energy capacity. Data is freely available from the World Bank.

title: Time Series Analysis
text:
A time series is any sequence of measurements taken at regular, equally spaced intervals—seconds, minutes, hours, days, months, quarters, or years. Common examples include weather (daily temperature or rainfall), financial markets (daily stock prices or returns), industry indicators (monthly production or sales), electricity demand, traffic counts, and hospital admissions. In time-series analysis we study how these values evolve: their level, trend, seasonal or calendar patterns (e.g., weekdays vs. weekends, holiday effects), cycles, and anomalies. Typical goals are to describe behavior clearly, forecast future values, and quantify the impact of events or policies.
Because observations are ordered in time, nearby points tend to be correlated (autocorrelation). This violates the independent-and-identically-distributed assumption behind many standard statistical methods, so naïve cross-sectional tools often mislead. Time-series work must explicitly handle dependence, trend, and seasonality—for example by differencing, seasonal adjustment, and models that use lagged values and errors (e.g., ARIMA/SARIMA, ARIMAX/SARIMAX with external drivers, VAR for multiple series, state-space/ETS, or GARCH when volatility changes over time). Analysts also watch for structural breaks (e.g., policy shifts, COVID), outliers, and missing periods, and they evaluate models with time-aware validation (rolling or blocked splits) rather than random shuffles.

text:

title: EDA
text:
Code
library(dplyr)
library(tseries)
library(stringr)
library(plotly)
library(scales)
library(ggplot2)
library(quantmod)
library(tidyquant)
library(tidyverse) 
library(forecast)
library(gridExtra)
library(lubridate)
Code
df <- read.csv("data/electric.csv")
df <- df %>%
  mutate(
    Description = str_extract(Description, "(?<=From ).*?(?=,)"),
    YYYYMM = as.character(YYYYMM),
    Year = as.integer(substr(YYYYMM, 1, 4)),
    Month = as.integer(substr(YYYYMM, 5, 6))
  ) %>%
  filter(Month <= 12) %>%
  filter(Year >= 2000) %>%
  mutate(Date = as.Date(paste(Year, Month, "01", sep = "-")))
Code
etf_symbols <- c("ICLN", "XLE")

etf_data <- tq_get(etf_symbols,
                   from = "2000-01-01",
                   to = Sys.Date(),
                   get = "stock.prices")

icln_monthly <- etf_data %>%
  filter(symbol == "ICLN") %>%
  tq_transmute(select = adjusted,
               mutate_fun = to.monthly,
               indexAt = "lastof",
               col_rename = "adjusted")

ts_icln <- ts(icln_monthly$adjusted,
              start = c(year(min(icln_monthly$date)), month(min(icln_monthly$date))),
              frequency = 12)

xle_monthly <- etf_data %>%
  filter(symbol == "XLE") %>%
  tq_transmute(select = adjusted,
               mutate_fun = to.monthly,
               indexAt = "lastof",
               col_rename = "adjusted")

ts_xle <- ts(xle_monthly$adjusted,
              start = c(year(min(xle_monthly$date)), month(min(xle_monthly$date))),
              frequency = 12)
Code
df_n <- read.csv("data/naturalgasprice.csv")
df_n<- df_n %>%
  mutate(
    YYYYMM = as.character(YYYYMM),
    Year = as.integer(substr(YYYYMM, 1, 4)),
    Month = as.integer(substr(YYYYMM, 5, 6))
  ) %>%
  filter(Month <= 12) %>%
  filter(Year >= 2000) %>%
  mutate(Value = as.numeric(Value)) %>%
  mutate(Date = as.Date(paste(Year, Month, "01", sep = "-")))%>%
  arrange(Date)

ts_np <- ts(df_n$Value,
              start = c(min(df_n$Year), min(df_n$Month)),
              frequency = 12)

title: EDA
text:
Time Series Plot

WindCoalNatural GasNuclear Electric PowerHydroelectric PowerSolarWTI Oil priceHenry Hub Natural Gas priceRenewable Energy ETF (ICLN)Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLE)




Code
wind_df <- df %>%
  filter(Description == "Wind") %>%
  filter(!is.na(Value)) %>% 
  mutate(Value = as.numeric(Value)) %>%
  arrange(Date)

ts_wind <- ts(wind_df$Value,
              start = c(min(wind_df$Year), min(wind_df$Month)),
              frequency = 12)

p <- autoplot(ts_wind, colour = "darkblue") +
  ggtitle("Wind Electricity Net Generation")+
  xlab("Time") +
  ylab("Value") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p)   






The time series of wind electricity net generation from 2000 to 2025 reveals a pronounced upward trend, reflecting the rapid expansion of renewable energy capacity. It also exhibits strong seasonality, with recurring intra-annual fluctuations linked to climatic conditions and demand cycles. Moreover, the increasing amplitude of variation over time suggests rising volatility as generation scales up. These features imply that forecasting requires models capable of addressing both trend and seasonality, while the observed dynamics underscore the growing significance of wind energy in the energy transition and the operational challenges of managing its variability.




Code
coal_df <- df %>%
  filter(Description == "Coal") %>%
  filter(!is.na(Value)) %>% 
  mutate(Value = as.numeric(Value)) %>%
  arrange(Date)

ts_coal <- ts(coal_df$Value,
              start = c(min(coal_df$Year), min(coal_df$Month)),
              frequency = 12)

p <- autoplot(ts_coal, colour = "darkblue") +
  ggtitle("Coal Electricity Net Generation") +
  xlab("Time") +
  ylab("Value") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p) 






The time series of coal electricity net generation exhibits a pronounced long-term declining trend, particularly evident after 2010. This structural downturn is accompanied by persistent seasonal fluctuations, indicative of cyclical demand for electricity. The abrupt decline starting around 2012 likely corresponds with policy shifts, environmental regulations, and the increasing competitiveness of alternative energy sources such as natural gas and renewables. The data reflects a fundamental transformation in the energy mix, with coal playing a diminishing role in electricity generation.




Code
n_df <- df %>%
  filter(Description == "Natural Gas") %>%
  filter(!is.na(Value)) %>% 
  mutate(Value = as.numeric(Value)) %>%
  arrange(Date)

ts_n <- ts(n_df$Value,
              start = c(min(n_df$Year), min(n_df$Month)),
              frequency = 12)

p <- autoplot(ts_n, colour = "darkblue") +
  ggtitle("Natural Gas Electricity Net Generation") +
  xlab("Time") +
  ylab("Value") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p) 






The net electricity generation from natural gas shows a pronounced upward trend, indicating its growing role as a transitional energy source. It also exhibits strong seasonality, with recurring intra-annual fluctuations linked to climatic conditions and demand cycles. This expansion is driven by the relative cost-efficiency of natural gas, its abundance in domestic supply, and its lower carbon intensity compared with coal. The increasing reliance on natural gas highlights its strategic importance in meeting rising energy demand while supporting decarbonization goals, positioning it as a central component of the evolving energy mix.




Code
nuclear_df <- df %>%
  filter(Description == "Nuclear Electric Power") %>%
  filter(!is.na(Value)) %>% 
  mutate(Value = as.numeric(Value)) %>%
  arrange(Date)

ts_nuclear <- ts(nuclear_df$Value,
              start = c(min(nuclear_df$Year), min(nuclear_df$Month)),
              frequency = 12)

p <- autoplot(ts_nuclear, colour = "darkblue") +
  ggtitle("Nuclear Electric Power Electricity Net Generation") +
  xlab("Time") +
  ylab("Value") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p) 






The net electricity generation from nuclear power remains relatively stable over time, reflecting its role as a consistent baseload energy source. Although growth has been limited compared to renewables, nuclear energy continues to provide reliable, low-carbon electricity that supports energy security and decarbonization objectives. Its long-term stability highlights both the technological maturity of nuclear power and the challenges of expanding capacity due to safety concerns, high capital costs, and lengthy regulatory processes.




Code
hy_df <- df %>%
  filter(Description == "Conventional Hydroelectric Power") %>%
  filter(!is.na(Value)) %>% 
  mutate(Value = as.numeric(Value)) %>%
  arrange(Date)

ts_hy <- ts(hy_df$Value,
              start = c(min(hy_df$Year), min(hy_df$Month)),
              frequency = 12)

p <- autoplot(ts_hy, colour = "darkblue") +
  ggtitle("Hydroelectric Power Electricity Net Generation") +
  xlab("Time") +
  ylab("Value") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p) 






The net electricity generation from hydroelectric power shows a relatively steady pattern with modest fluctuations, largely influenced by hydrological conditions and regional water resource availability. While it remains a mature and established renewable source, the absence of significant long-term growth reflects geographical and environmental constraints that limit large-scale expansion. Nevertheless, hydroelectricity continues to play a crucial role in providing reliable renewable energy and grid stability, particularly through its flexibility in balancing intermittent solar and wind generation.




Code
solar_df <- df %>%
  filter(Description == "Solar") %>%
  filter(!is.na(Value)) %>% 
  mutate(Value = as.numeric(Value)) %>%
  arrange(Date)

ts_solar <- ts(solar_df$Value,
              start = c(min(solar_df$Year), min(solar_df$Month)),
              frequency = 12)

p <- autoplot(ts_solar, colour = "darkblue") +
  ggtitle("Solar Electricity Net Generation") +
  xlab("Time") +
  ylab("Value") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p) 






The net electricity generation from solar energy demonstrates a strong upward trajectory, reflecting rapid technological advancements, declining production costs, and supportive policy frameworks. This rise underscores the increasing competitiveness of solar power within the broader energy market, as well as its central role in advancing decarbonization and sustainable development objectives. The accelerating growth also highlights shifting investment priorities toward renewable energy and the expanding societal demand for cleaner electricity sources.




Code
wti <- read.csv("data/WTIprice.csv")
wti <- wti %>%
  rename(date = observation_date) %>%
  mutate(date = as.Date(date)) %>%
  rename(WTI = POILWTIUSDM) %>%
  mutate(WTI = as.numeric(WTI))

ts_wti <- ts(wti$WTI,
              start = c(1990, 1),
              frequency = 12)

p <- autoplot(ts_wti, colour = "darkblue") +
  ggtitle("WTI Oil price")+
  xlab("Time") +
  ylab("Value") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p)   






The historical trend of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil prices is characterized by pronounced volatility, reflecting the commodity’s sensitivity to global supply-demand dynamics, geopolitical tensions, and macroeconomic cycles. Periods of sharp spikes, such as during the mid-2000s oil boom, and dramatic collapses, such as in 2008 and 2020, illustrate the market’s exposure to both financial crises and unprecedented demand shocks. Despite these fluctuations, WTI oil remains a key global benchmark, and its long-term movements serve as a critical indicator of energy market stability, investment strategies, and the broader transition toward alternative energy sources.




Code
p <- autoplot(ts_np, colour = "darkblue") +
  ggtitle("Henry Hub Natural Gas price ")+
  xlab("Time") +
  ylab("Value") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p)  






The Henry Hub natural gas price series exhibits strong seasonal patterns superimposed on a gradually increasing trend. The clear and recurring intra-annual fluctuations reflect consistent seasonal demand cycles, likely driven by heating and cooling needs. Notable volatility spikes, such as those observed in 2008 and 2022, suggest the influence of external shocks or supply disruptions. Unlike the Renewable Energy ETF (ICLN), this series demonstrates more regular and predictable dynamics, indicative of a mature commodity market responsive to both fundamental and cyclical factors.




Code
p <- autoplot(ts_icln, colour = "darkblue") +
  ggtitle("Renewable Energy ETF (ICLN) ")+
  xlab("Time") +
  ylab("Value") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p)  






The historical price trend of the Renewable Energy ETF (ICLN) reveals a long-term upward movement interrupted by significant short-term volatility. The sharp rise during 2020–2021 likely reflects heightened investor interest in clean energy, possibly influenced by political shifts and global ESG momentum. However, the subsequent decline suggests either market correction or reduced optimism. While no clear seasonal pattern is observed, the data displays cyclic behavior tied to broader macroeconomic and policy-related factors, implying that the clean energy sector is both promising and highly reactive to external stimuli.




Code
p <- autoplot(ts_xle, colour = "darkblue") +
  ggtitle("Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLE)")+
  xlab("Time") +
  ylab("Value") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p)  






The time series of the Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLE) displays a long-term upward trend with significant cyclical fluctuations that broadly align with major energy market dynamics. Periods of sharp decline, such as during the 2008 financial crisis and the 2020 pandemic shock, indicate the fund’s sensitivity to macroeconomic downturns and global oil price collapses. While no clear seasonality is evident, the repeated boom–bust cycles reflect the commodity-linked nature of the energy sector, driven by supply-demand imbalances, geopolitical shocks, and structural shifts in global energy consumption. Notably, the strong recovery after 2020 underscores renewed investor confidence in traditional energy despite the concurrent growth of renewable alternatives. This suggests that fossil fuel–linked equities remain resilient and strategically significant in the evolving energy mix.

title: EDA
text:
Lag plot

WindCoalNatural GasNuclear Electric PowerHydroelectric PowerSolarWTI Oil priceHenry Hub Natural Gas priceRenewable Energy ETF (ICLN)Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLE)




Code
gglagplot(ts_wind, do.lines=FALSE) +xlab("Lags")+ylab("Value")+ggtitle("Lag Plot for wind")+theme(axis.text.x=element_text(angle=45, hjust=1))









The autocorrelation across all lags is very strong here.




Code

The power has the strongest autocorrelation at lag 12. However, the other shows weak autocorrelation.




Code
gglagplot(ts_n, do.lines=FALSE) +xlab("Lags")+ylab("Value")+ggtitle("Lag Plot for natural gas")+theme(axis.text.x=element_text(angle=45, hjust=1))   









The power has the strongest autocorrelation at lag 12. However, the other shows weak autocorrelation.

title: Introduction
text:
The world is undergoing a profound transformation in how energy is produced, consumed, and financed. Historically, global economic growth has been tightly coupled with fossil fuels such as oil, coal, and natural gas. However, mounting evidence of climate change, advances in clean technologies, and shifting government policies have accelerated the global transition toward renewable energy. This transition—often described as the “energy transition”—is reshaping markets, altering geopolitical balances, and influencing the financial system.
From a data science perspective, this topic provides a unique opportunity to explore long-term structural trends alongside short-term volatility. Energy data exhibits strong seasonality (e.g., higher natural gas demand in winter, increased electricity demand during summer heat waves), as well as structural breaks (such as the 2015 Paris Agreement or the 2020 oil price crash). It also connects multiple domains: technology costs, consumer behavior, financial market reactions, and environmental policy.
Understanding these dynamics is not just an academic exercise—governments, investors, and industries rely on such analyses to guide decision-making in the face of uncertainty.

title: Introduction
text:
The Big Picture





The global shift to clean energy is one of the most significant transformations shaping the 21st-century economy, with implications spanning technology, markets, policy, and finance. This analysis will consider the following five main areas:
Renewable Energy Growth and Seasonality: The expansion of solar, wind, and hydropower is central to the energy transition. However, their seasonal and intermittent nature introduces challenges for grid stability and demand–supply balancing. Understanding these patterns is essential to evaluating the resilience and scalability of renewable energy systems.
Fossil Fuel Decline and Market Volatility: As coal, oil, and natural gas face structural decline, markets are experiencing heightened volatility and price fluctuations. Analyzing these dynamics provides insights into the risks for energy security and the broader macroeconomic consequences of decarbonization.
echnological Innovation (EVs and Batteries): Advances in electric vehicles, battery storage, hydrogen, and smart grids serve as key enablers of the clean energy transition. This section will examine how technological progress reduces costs, enhances efficiency, and accelerates the adoption of sustainable energy systems.
Policy and Regulation: The global energy transition is profoundly shaped by regulatory frameworks and government interventions. Carbon pricing, renewable portfolio standards, subsidies, and international agreements—particularly the Paris Agreement—are decisive factors in aligning national policies with global climate goals.
Global Investment and Capital Flows: Financing the clean energy transition requires large-scale capital mobilization. The rise of green finance, ESG-driven strategies, and fossil fuel divestment initiatives highlights the financial sector’s pivotal role in driving systemic change. This section will investigate how capital allocation patterns influence the speed and direction of global decarbonization.

title: Introduction
text:
Literature Review
Seasonality in Renewable Energy
Prakash et al. (2025) investigate the role of seasonal and weather-driven variation in renewable energy production, with a focus on solar and wind power. Using SARIMA and hybrid decomposition models, they show that seasonal patterns in electricity generation strongly influence short-term grid balancing and long-term planning. Their findings indicate that reliable time-series modeling of seasonality is essential for forecasting renewable output and preventing mismatches between energy supply and demand. This work highlights the importance of seasonality in renewable energy markets and supports the use of SARIMA and SARIMAX approaches in analyzing cyclical adoption patterns in our project1.
Volatility in Fossil Fuel and Energy Finance
Narayan and Sharma (2019) examine volatility clustering in oil and natural gas prices, applying GARCH and EGARCH models to capture periods of heightened market uncertainty. Their results demonstrate that fossil fuel prices are subject to strong regime shifts triggered by geopolitical shocks and OPEC decisions, producing spillovers in energy-related financial markets2. Similarly, Wang and Zhou (2021) find that policy announcements often induce short-lived but sharp volatility spikes in energy stock indices3. These studies underscore the need to apply GARCH-type volatility models when studying fossil fuels and renewable-related financial assets, as fluctuations in fossil prices are deeply tied to the broader energy transition.
Technological Change and EV Adoption
Nykvist and Nilsson (2015) analyze the long-run cost trajectory of lithium-ion batteries, documenting a steep decline that has accelerated global electric vehicle (EV) adoption4. Their study highlights a learning-curve dynamic, where technological improvements and scale economies reduce costs over time, producing a logistic diffusion pattern in EV sales. Zaino et al. (2024) extend this analysis by modeling EV adoption using ARIMAX and logistic growth models, showing that cost reductions coupled with infrastructure investment generate rapid market penetration5. Together, these studies illustrate the technological drivers of clean energy adoption and provide a foundation for modeling structural transitions in EV markets.
Policy Shocks and Carbon Pricing
Rafaty et al. (2022) explore the effects of climate policy interventions—such as carbon pricing and renewable energy subsidies—on investment and adoption patterns across OECD countries6. Their study finds that policy shocks often create measurable breaks in time series, with rapid increases in renewable deployment following major policy announcements. Similarly, World Bank (2023) reports demonstrate that countries implementing carbon pricing achieve more stable emissions reductions compared to those relying solely on voluntary targets7. These findings emphasize the importance of including exogenous policy dummies and interrupted time-series models to capture the role of policy in accelerating the energy transition.
Global Energy Markets and Transition Risks
BloombergNEF (2023) reviews global investment trends in renewable energy and battery storage, finding that despite rising capital flows into clean technologies, fossil fuel assets continue to dominate some regions8. Their analysis shows that currency fluctuations, commodity price swings, and investor sentiment significantly affect the pace of capital reallocation from fossil fuels to renewables. This aligns with the view that the energy transition involves both structural long-term change and short-term volatility, requiring a blend of VAR, ARFIMA, and deep learning models to forecast interconnected global markets.

title: Introduction
text:
Guiding Questions

How have seasonal patterns in oil and natural gas demand evolved over the past decades?
Can traditional energy price shocks (e.g., oil crises) be forecast using ARIMA or SARIMA models?
What long-term growth trends can be identified in renewable energy generation capacity?
To what extent does renewable adoption follow exponential or logistic growth patterns?
How do oil price fluctuations impact the stock returns of fossil fuel companies compared to renewable firms?
Does renewable energy stock volatility exhibit clustering effects that can be modeled with GARCH?
How strongly are electric vehicle sales correlated with declining battery costs?
What structural breaks (e.g., the 2015 Paris Agreement, 2020 COVID-19 shock) can be detected in energy markets?
How do carbon pricing policies influence CO₂ emissions reductions across regions?
What predictive insights can deep learning models (e.g., LSTM) provide about renewable adoption in the next decade?
Do renewable investments reduce dependence on fossil fuel imports, as reflected in trade and price series?
How do government subsidies shift the balance of energy investments in different countries?

text:
Examine how the composition of power generation (wind, solar, coal, natural gas, nuclear, hydro) has evolved over time and how each source exhibits seasonal patterns. This captures the structural shift of the energy transition.

df <- read.csv("data/electric.csv")
df <- df %>%
  mutate(
    Description = str_extract(Description, "(?<=From ).*?(?=,)"),

title: ARMA, ARIMA, and SARIMA Models
text:
Wind


Code
wind_df <- df %>%
  filter(Description == "Wind") %>%
  filter(!is.na(Value)) %>% 
  mutate(Value = as.numeric(Value)) %>%
  arrange(Date)

ts_wind <- ts(wind_df$Value,
              start = c(min(wind_df$Year), min(wind_df$Month)),
              frequency = 12)



Log TransformationSeasonal DifferencingAugmented Dickey-Fuller TestACF and PACFManual ARIMAModel diagnostic and equationauto.arima()ForecastingBenchmark


The log-transformed, first-differenced series is more stationary than the first difference of the original scale. In the original-scale differences, variability increases toward the end—evidence of heteroskedasticity and residual non-stationarity. The log transform stabilizes the variance, so the differenced log series fluctuates around a roughly constant mean with nearly constant variation. However, the ACF still shows seasonal dependence (spikes at lags 12, 24, …). To address this remaining structure, we should apply a seasonal difference on top of the ordinary difference—i.e., compute —to remove the seasonal correlation.


Code
# Extract vectors
dates <- wind_df$Date
y     <- as.numeric(wind_df$Value)

diff_orig <- diff(y)
diff_log  <- diff(log(pmax(y, .Machine$double.eps)))  # safe log if any zeros
date_d    <- dates[-1]

# Data frames for ggplot
df_orig <- data.frame(Date = date_d, Diff = diff_orig)
df_log  <- data.frame(Date = date_d, Diff = diff_log)

# Panel 1: differenced original
p1 <- ggplot(df_orig, aes(x = Date, y = Diff)) +
  geom_line(color = "steelblue") +
  labs(title = "First Difference (Original Scale)",
       x = "Year", y = "First Difference") +
  scale_x_date(date_labels = "%Y", date_breaks = "5 years") +
  theme_minimal()

# Panel 2: differenced log
p2 <- ggplot(df_log, aes(x = Date, y = Diff)) +
  geom_line(color = "firebrick") +
  labs(title = "First Difference (Log Scale)",
       x = "Year", y = "First Difference (log)") +
  scale_x_date(date_labels = "%Y", date_breaks = "5 years") +
  theme_minimal()

# Stack vertically
p1 / p2











ACF: Original series. Here it is evident that there is very high autocorrelation, including seasonal correlation, with highly significant serial correlation at seasonal lags. However, due to heteroscedasticity in the data, we need a log transformation.
ACF: log(xt) — ordinary diff. Here we can see the ordinary serial correlation is minimal compared to the raw series data ACF, but there is high seasonal correlation remains at lags 12, 24, etc. So we will need seasonal differencing.
ACF: log(xt) — seasonal diff. Here, when we apply seasonal differencing, we can see that the seasonal correlation has become very small, but the series is still not stationary due to high correlation from the ordinary lags. Our goal is to convert the data into a stationary process as a first step for our modeling process; therefore, we need both ordinary differencing on top of seasonal differencing.
ACF: log(xt) — ordinary + seasonal diff. With both ordinary and seasonal differencing, the series is now more stationary.


Code
# Log series (safe for zeros)
log_ts  <- log(pmax(ts_wind, .Machine$double.eps))

# Differencing
d_log   <- diff(log_ts)              # ordinary diff of log
sd_log  <- diff(log_ts, lag = 12)    # seasonal diff of log
osd_log <- diff(d_log,  lag = 12)    # first + seasonal diff of log

# ACF plots
p1 <- ggAcf(ts_wind,   lag.max = 60) + ggtitle("ACF: Original series") +
  theme_minimal()
p2 <- ggAcf(d_log,   lag.max = 60) + ggtitle("ACF: log(xt)-ordinary diff)") +
  theme_minimal()
p3 <- ggAcf(sd_log,  lag.max = 60) + ggtitle("ACF: log(xt)-seasonal diff") +
  theme_minimal()
p4 <- ggAcf(osd_log, lag.max = 60) + ggtitle("ACF:log(xt)-ordinary + seasonal diff") +
  theme_minimal()

# Arrange in a 2x2 grid
(p1 | p2) / (p3 | p4)

grid.arrange(acf, pacf, nrow=2)













Code
SARIMA.c=function(p1,p2,q1,q2,P1,P2,Q1,Q2,data){
  
  temp=c()
  d=1
  D=1
  s=12
  
  i=1
  temp= data.frame()
  ls=matrix(rep(NA,9*35),nrow=35)
  for (p in p1:p2)
  {
    for(q in q1:q2)
    {
      for(P in P1:P2)
      {
        for(Q in Q1:Q2)
        {
          if(p+d+q+P+D+Q<=9)
          {
            model<- Arima(data,order=c(p-1,d,q-1),seasonal=c(P-1,D,Q-1))
            ls[i,]= c(p-1,d,q-1,P-1,D,Q-1,model$aic,model$bic,model$aicc)
            i=i+1
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
  
  temp= as.data.frame(ls)
  names(temp)= c("p","d","q","P","D","Q","AIC","BIC","AICc")
  temp
}

output=SARIMA.c(p1=1,p2=5,q1=1,q2=3,P1=1,P2=3,Q1=1,Q2=3,data=log_ts)
output[which.min(output$AIC),] 


   p d q P D Q       AIC       BIC      AICc
25 1 1 1 0 1 1 -311.6715 -296.9508 -311.5326





Standardized Residuals: The residuals fluctuate randomly around zero with no visible trend or seasonal pattern. Variance appears stable over time. Suggests residuals behave like white noise.
ACF of Residuals: Most autocorrelations are within the blue confidence bounds.No significant spikes → no serial correlation remains. Indicates good model fit.
Normal Q–Q Plot: Points mostly lie on the 45° line, with slight deviation in the tails. Minor departure from normality at extremes, but acceptable for large samples.
Ljung–Box Test p-values: Many p-values fall below 0.05, which suggests that some autocorrelation remains in the residuals. Therefore, the white-noise assumption is not fully met, and the model may still have room for improvement.

The ARIMA(1,1,1)(0,1,1)[12] model provides a reasonable forecast for wind electricity net generation.
The results suggest that:

Wind electricity generation will continue increasing in the coming years, following the established long-term growth trend.
Seasonal fluctuations remain evident, showing that generation tends to rise and fall periodically (likely due to seasonal wind patterns).

fit %>% forecast(h=36) %>% autoplot() #next 3 years












The ARIMA model outperforms all benchmark models.
This indicates ARIMA captures both the underlying trend and seasonality of the wind generation data, making it the most reliable forecasting model among those tested.

Code
# Compute Accuracy Metrics Safely
get_acc <- function(model, name) {
  acc <- as.data.frame(accuracy(model))
  rownames(acc) <- NULL
  acc$Method <- name
  return(acc)
}

acc_list <- list(
  get_acc(mean_forecast, "Mean"),
  get_acc(naive_forecast, "Naïve"),
  get_acc(snaive_forecast, "SNaïve"),
  get_acc(drift_forecast, "Drift"),
  get_acc(arima_forecast, "ARIMA")
)

acc_df <- dplyr::bind_rows(acc_list)

acc_summary <- acc_df %>%
  dplyr::select(Method, RMSE, MAE, MAPE, MASE, ACF1) %>%
  dplyr::distinct()

Code
hy_df <- df %>%

Seasonal DifferencingAugmented Dickey-Fuller TestACF and PACFManual ARIMAModel diagnostic and equationauto.arima()ForecastingBenchmark


ACF: First diff, there is high seasonal correlation remains at lags 12, 24, etc. So we will need seasonal differencing.
ACF: SSeasonal diff. Here, when we apply seasonal differencing, we can see that the seasonal correlation has become very small, but the series is still not stationary due to high correlation from the ordinary lags. Our goal is to convert the data into a stationary process as a first step for our modeling process; therefore, we need both ordinary differencing on top of seasonal differencing.
ACF: First + seasonal diff. With both ordinary and seasonal differencing, the series is now more stationary.

  theme_minimal()

  theme_minimal()

Code
SARIMA.c=function(p1,p2,q1,q2,P1,P2,Q1,Q2,data){
  
  temp=c()
  d=1
  D=1
  s=12
  
  i=1
  temp= data.frame()
  ls=matrix(rep(NA,9*35),nrow=35)
  for (p in p1:p2)
  {
    for(q in q1:q2)
    {
      for(P in P1:P2)
      {
        for(Q in Q1:Q2)
        {
          if(p+d+q+P+D+Q<=9)
          {
            model<- Arima(data,order=c(p-1,d,q-1),seasonal=c(P-1,D,Q-1))
            ls[i,]= c(p-1,d,q-1,P-1,D,Q-1,model$aic,model$bic,model$aicc)
            i=i+1
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
  
  temp= as.data.frame(ls)
  names(temp)= c("p","d","q","P","D","Q","AIC","BIC","AICc")
  temp
}

output=SARIMA.c(p1=1,p2=3,q1=1,q2=3,P1=1,P2=5,Q1=1,Q2=3,data=ts_hy)
output[which.min(output$AIC),] 


   p d q P D Q      AIC      BIC     AICc
26 1 1 1 0 1 1 5231.433 5246.154 5231.572





Standardized Residuals: The residuals fluctuate randomly around zero with no visible trend or seasonal pattern. Variance appears stable over time. Suggests residuals behave like white noise.
ACF of Residuals: All autocorrelations are within the blue confidence bounds.No significant spikes → no serial correlation remains. Indicates good model fit.
Normal Q–Q Plot: Points mostly lie on the 45° line, with slight deviation in the tails. Minor departure from normality at extremes, but acceptable for large samples.
Ljung–Box Test p-values: Most p-values above 0.05 across lags → we fail to reject the null hypothesis of no autocorrelation. Residuals are uncorrelated.

\]

SARIMA.c=function(p1,p2,q1,q2,P1,P2,Q1,Q2,data){
  
  temp=c()
  d=1
  D=1
  s=12
  
  i=1
  temp= data.frame()
  ls=matrix(rep(NA,9*35),nrow=35)
  for (p in p1:p2)
  {
    for(q in q1:q2)
    {
      for(P in P1:P2)
      {
        for(Q in Q1:Q2)
        {
          if(p+d+q+P+D+Q<=9)
          {
            model<- Arima(data,order=c(p-1,d,q-1),seasonal=c(P-1,D,Q-1))
            ls[i,]= c(p-1,d,q-1,P-1,D,Q-1,model$aic,model$bic,model$aicc)
            i=i+1
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
  
  temp= as.data.frame(ls)
  names(temp)= c("p","d","q","P","D","Q","AIC","BIC","AICc")
  temp
}

  filter(!is.na(Value)) %>%

  arrange(Date)

              start = c(min(n_df$Year), min(n_df$Month)),

Seasonal DifferencingAugmented Dickey-Fuller TestACF and PACFManual ARIMAModel diagnostic and equationauto.arima()ForecastingBenchmark


ACF: First diff, there is high seasonal correlation remains at lags 12, 24, etc. So we will need seasonal differencing.
ACF: SSeasonal diff. Here, when we apply seasonal differencing, we can see that the seasonal correlation has become very small, but the series is still not stationary due to high correlation from the ordinary lags. Our goal is to convert the data into a stationary process as a first step for our modeling process; therefore, we need both ordinary differencing on top of seasonal differencing.
ACF: First + seasonal diff. With both ordinary and seasonal differencing, the series is now more stationary.


Code

sd <- diff(ts_n, lag = 12)    
osd <- diff(d,  lag = 12)    # first + seasonal diff of log

  theme_minimal()

  theme_minimal()
